fieldNotes: Cespitose with seven stems, 8-10 m tall, dbh 10-15 cm. Stem green, armed, numerous spines (1-5 cm long) between leaf-scars. Distance between leaf-scars 20 cm. A sword is present. Leaves 10-15, 3 x 0.6 m. Old leaves persistent, 0.5-1 m below the green ones. Pinnae 2 x 120, recurved, yellowish tinged, green on both sides, nervation light green. Inflorescence infrafoliar, prophyll not seen. First bract 45 x 15 cm, spathulate and spiny. Peduncle green and ferrugineous pubescent, 15-20 cm. Rachis green, 30 cm long. Spicate 1. order rachillae to 15 cm. Fruit bright red at maturity. V.n.: Chontillo (spanish). Use: Fruits are edible, boiled. Each infructescence is worth 2o sucres on the local market. Duplicates: AAU, QCA, QCNE.
FieldNotes: Cespitose with seven stems, 8-10 m tall, dbh 10-15 cm. Stem green, armed, numerous spines (1-5 cm long) between leaf-scars. Distance between leaf-scars 20 cm. A sword is present. Spicate 1. order rachillae to 15 cm. Fruit bright red at maturity. V.n.: Chontillo (spanish). Use: Fruits are edible, boiled. Each infructescence is worth 2o sucres on the local market. Duplicates: AAU, QCA, QCNE.

fieldNotes: Stem solitary, green, smooth, 6 m tall, 8 cm diam, nodes 15-20 cm apart. Leaves 6; sheaths forming a prominent green crownshaft 65 cm long; petiole 25 cm long, channelled above, rounded below with sharp margins; rachis 130 cm long, ridged above, rounded below; pinnae 25 per side, lower one 15 x 1 cm, middle one 86 x 6 cm, upper one 48 x 4 cm, evenly spaced and all in one horizontal plane. Inflorescence buds 6 per node, all staminate, pendulous at anthesis, joined at base by a rim on the stem; peduncle 28 cm long with prophyll and 3 bracts; rachis 22 cm long; rachillae 48, 3-9 cm long, unbranched.

fieldNotes: Solitary palm. Stem 430 cm long from base to crownshaft. Dbh. 6.0 cm, diam. just below crownshaft 5.4 cm. Stem with numerous adventitious roots at the base and from 140 cm above the ground where the stem was damaged. Leavea 4+1 juvenile. Leafsheath 59 cm long, petiole 14 cm long, rachis 144 cm long. Pinnae 2 x 23. Basal pinnae 39 x 4.1 cm erect, middle pinnae 62 x 7 cm, apical pinnae 26 x ? cm. Infructescences: 3 inserted at the apical 3 nodes. Mature infructescence: peduncle 38 cm long, green, cross section ovate, largest diam. below the basal rachillae 1.7 cm. Number of bracts: prophyll and 5 peduncular bracts, all deciduos. Rachis 6 cm long, green. Rachillae: 8. Basal rachillae 34 cm long, apical rachillae 31 cm long. Mature fruits red, globular, 1.9 cm in diam. Fruits said to be eaten by a small rodent called Ardilla (Antonio). Kromosome test: m. hydroxychinoline n. 23 m. clark n. 28

fieldNotes: Solitary palm. Stem 610 cm from base to crownshaft, green with conspicuous nodes. Dbh. 5.4 cm. Base of stem with numerous adventitious roots forming a cone 65 cm tall 35 cm in diam. Leafsheath 83 cm long, encircling the stem for 75 cm thus forming a crownshaft. No. of leaves 5 + 1 juvenile. Petiole 15 cm long, rachis 148 cm long. No. of pinnae 2 x 26. Basal pinnae: 41 x 23 cm, mid pinnae: 69 x 9.1 cm, apical pinnae: 24 x 5.4 cm. No visible inflorescences but nuds beneath each of the leafsheaths. No. buds per node 13. Dupl.: AAU, QCA, QCNE.

fieldNotes: Solitary palm. Stem 385 cm long. Dbh. 3.5 cm. No. of leaves 5 + 1 juvenile. Leafsheath 45 cm long, encircling the stem for 24 cm. Petiole 18 cm long. Rachis 122 cm long. No. of pinnae 2 x 21. Basal pinnae: 30 x 3.5 cm, mid pinnae 45 x 7 cm, apical pinnae 23 x 3.7. Inflorescences: At 1st node: 1 inflorescence creased flowering and 1 decaying; at 2nd node: 2 inflorescences both decaying; at 3rd node: 1 infructescence with green fruits. Inflorescence: Petiole 11.5 cm long. No. of bracts: 1 prophyll and 4 peduncular bracts. Rachis 7.5 cm long. No. of rachillae 13. Basal rachillae 7.5 cm long, apical rachillae 3.5 cm long. Inflorescences creamy white. Dupl. QCA, QCNE.

fieldNotes: Solitary palm. Stem 462 cm long from base to crownshaft. Dbh. 5.5 cm. Stem green glabrous with conspicuous nodes. No. of leaves 7 + 1 juvenile. Leafsheath 77 cm long encircling the stem for 35 cm. Petiole 33 cm long. Rachis 175 cm long. No. of pinnae 2 x 25. Pinnae inserted in one plane on the apical part of the rachis and in an angel of 45° on the basal part og the rachis. 1 inflorescence infrafoliar. Peduncle 24 cm long. Rachis 3 cm long. No. of rachillae 5. Peduncle, rachis, rachillae and flowers creamy white. Fruit (from another individual) globular, glabrous, orange. Dupl. QCA, QCNE.

fieldNotes: Solitary. Stem 7 m tall, 7 cm diam. at base, 5 cm diam. at apex, green, smooth, conspicously ringed by leafscars. Leaves 5; sheaths green, smooth, closed, forming a 85 cm long crownshaft; petiole 70-80 cm long, rachis 190-210 cm long, both green, smooth; pinnae 17 per side, regularly inserted, subequal, in one plane, middle pinnae 70 x 15 cm. Infructescences infrafoliar, 1 or 2 per node. Mature fruits red, 28 x 25 mm. Dupl.: AAU, QCA, QCNE, COL, NY.

fieldNotes: Stem solitary, erect, green, 2.5 -4 m tall, 4 -6 cm diam., nodes 2 -4 cm apart. Leaves 3 -5; sheaths forming a distinct green crownshaft 35 -58 cm long; petiole 24 cm long; rachis 150 cm long; pinnae 23 per side evenly spaced and in one plane, the lower 49 x 2 cm, the middle one 68 x 9 cm, the apical 34 x 8 cm. Immature fruits globose, green, ripening red, (same species as 62092, different from 62088).

fieldNotes: Stem solitary, erect, 5 m tall, 4 cm diam., green, with prominent nodes 13 cm apart. Leaves 5; sheaths forming a 50 cm dark green shaft; sheaths 60 cm; petiole 33 cm, grooved above, green; rachis 190 cm long; pinnae 19 per side, sigmoid, all in one plane, erectly spaced, equal, lower one 55 x 6 cm, middle one 80 x 11 cm, apical one 35 x 11 cm. Infructescences infrafoliar, solitary at nodes; peduncle 47 cm long, flattened; prophyll and 4 peduncular bracts; rachis 13 cm long; rachillae 14, 9 -12 cm long, immature fruits asymmetrical 2.5 x 2 cm, green.

Inflorescences 13 17 per node, erect in bud and at anthesis; peduncle 22 x 1 cm; rachis 10 cm; rachillae 38, 5 6 cm long; one prophyll and 4 peduncular bracts.

fieldNotes: Cespitose, growing in clumps of 6-8 stems, with numerous suckers at base or solitary. Stem up to 5 m tsll, 4 cm diam, internodes 3 cm on the upper part of the stem, light brown; the upper 70 cm of the stem covered with dead leafsheaths. Leaves 5; sheath 31 cm, open to the base, fibrous at margins forming a reticulate pattern, b/w photo after Aiphanes ph.; petiole ca. 10 cm, rounded below, flat above, dark red; rachis 62 cm, ridged above; pinnae 18 per side, 1-4 veined; strongly plicate; lower pinnae 28 x 3 cm, middle pinnae 35 x 4 cm, apical pinnae 26 x 2 cm. Inflorescence buds infrafoliar, protruding through the lower part of the supporting leafsheath, which splits dorsally and thus function as and extra protection of the inflorescence bud; prophyll 14 cm long, 5 cm wide, flat with two distinct margins above, rounded below, the wide margins forms a flat apically, woody, striate, often persistant in the aéarly stages of inflorescence development; peduncular bract 10-11 cm long, 5 cm wide, inserted ca. 1 cm above the prophyll, completely enclosed in the prophyll; rachillae much folded and twisted within the bracts, yellowish green, later becoming clear green. Inflorescences 1-2, infrafoliar; prophyll woody, striate ca. 10 cm long; peduncular bract not seen, inserted 2 cm above the prophyll; peduncle 12 cm, 2 cm wide; rachis 42 cm long; 1. order rachillae 15, the 6 simple; lower 1. order rachillae 31 cm, with 10 2. order rachillae, the upper 3 simple; 3. order rachillae ca. 14 cm long, 0.6 cm wide, green. Palm growing in recently burned forest. Proably capable of regenerating after a fire. Buds apparently protected by the leafsheaths.

fieldNotes: Solitary tree, 9 m tall. DBH: 8 cm. Stem smooth, brown and greyish patterned from lichens. A sword is present. Leaves 9, dim. (1.7 x 0.7)m. Leafsheath fibrous, yellow to brown. Petiole 15 cm. Leaves almost entire to divided. Pinnae reduplicately inserted on rachis, green on both sides, nervation conspicous yellow. Inflorescences infrafoliar. 4 mature and 3 buds on this specimen. Prophyll 30 x 10 cm, furrowed longitudinally, yellowish green. 1 sterile bract. Peduncle 5 cm, glabrous and green. Rachis to 50 cm, glabrous and green. To 22 1. order branches, each branching. Fruits sunken in floral branches. Fruit brownish red. Use: no information. Dubl.: AAU, QCA, QCNE.

fieldNotes: Solitary. Stem ca. 8 m, 8 - 9 cm diam., light brown, internodes 2 - 3 cm on the upper part of the stem. Leaves 11; sheath 53 cm, open to the base, red brown, with a fibrous margin; petiole 11 cm, 3.5 cm wide, rounded below, flattened above, green with a reddish tinge; rachis 136 cm; pinnae 54 per side, 1 - 3 veined, in groups of three 1- veined and one 3-veined pinnae, the 1-veined pinnae inserted horizontally, the 3-veined pinnae point upwards, thus giving the whole leaf a crispy appearance, lower pinnae 51 X 2.5 cm, middle pinnae (1-veined) 57 X 2.5 cm, middle pinnae (3-veined) 64 X 7.5 cm, apical pinnae 43 X 2.5 cm. Inflorescence buds infrafoliar; prophyll to 41 cm, 12 cm wide, glabrous, reddish brown; 1. peduncular bract 36 cm, 12 cm wide, completely enclosed in the prophyll, inserted 2 cm above prophyll, green; 2. peduncular bract 20 cm, split almost to base, inserted 3 cm above 1. peduncular bract; flowerpits glabrous inside; staminate flowers with reflexed anthers; pistillate flowers with a crenate staminodial tube. Inflorescences 2, infrafoliar, inserted 22 cm below lowermost leaf, to three times branched; prophyll not seen; peduncular bract not seen, inserted 1 cm above prophyll; peduncle 22 cm, 6 cm wide basally, 4 cm wide apically; rachis 60 cm; 1. order rachillae 23 - 28, the upper 6 - 11 simple; lower 1. order rachillae 32 cm, 2 cm wide, with 15 2. order rachillae, the upper 11 2. order rachillae simple, lower 2. order rachillae 5 cm, with three 3. order rachillae; upper 1. order rachillae 27 - 30 cm, 1 cm wide, green. Dupl. 6: AAU, QCA, QCNE
FieldNotes: Solitary. Stem ca. 8 m, 8 - 9 cm diam., light brown, internodes 2 - 3 cm on the upper part of the stem. Leaves 11; sheath 53 cm, open to the base, red brown, with a fibrous margin; petiole 11 cm, 3.5 cm wide, rounded below, flattened above, green with a reddish tinge; rachis 136 cm; pinnae 54 per side, 1 - 3 veined, in groups of three 1- veined and one 3-veined pinnae, the 1-veined pinnae inserted horizontally, the 3-veined pinnae point upwards, thus giving the whole leaf a crispy appearance, lower pinnae 51 X 2.5 cm, middle pinnae (1-veined) 57 X 2.5 cm, middle pinnae (3-veined) 64 X 7.5 cm, apical pinnae 43 X 2.5 cm. Inflorescence buds infrafoliar; prophyll to 41 cm, 12 cm wide, glabrous, reddish brown; 1. peduncular bract 36 cm, 12 cm wide, completely enclosed in the prophyll, inserted 2 cm above prophyll, green; 2. peduncular bract 20 cm, split almost to base, inserted 3 cm above 1. peduncular bract; flowerpits glabrous inside; staminate flowers with reflexed anthers; pistillate flowers with a crenate staminodial tube. Inflorescences 2, infrafoliar, inserted 22 cm below lowermost leaf, to three times branched; prophyll not seen; peduncular bract not seen, inserted 1 cm above prophyll; peduncle 22 cm, 6 cm wide basally, 4 cm wide apically; rachis 60 cm; 1. order rachillae 23 - 28, the upper 6 - 11 simple; lower 1. order rachillae 32 cm, 2 cm wide, with 15 2. order rachillae, the upper 11 2. order rachillae simple, lower 2. order rachillae 5 cm, with three 3. order rachillae; upper 1. order rachillae 27 - 30 cm, 1 cm wide, green. Dupl. 6: AAU, QCA, QCNE

fieldNotes: Solitary. Stem 8-9 m, 14 cm diam, internodes 5 cm basally, 2.5 cm apically. Leaves 12; sheath 70 cm. open to base, upper 15 cm bending away from stem, margins fibrous, forming a reticulate pattern, green covered with a white indumentum; petiole 24 cm, 4.5 cm wide, rounded below, with 2 grooves above; rachis 160 cm, triangular in c.s; pinnae 42 per side, regularly inserted, basal pinnae almost erect, distal pinnae almost horizontal, all pinnae with 1 prominent midrib and 2 x 3 2. veins; basal pinnae 52 x 4 cm, middle pinnae 62 x 6 cm, apical pinnae 35 x 5 cm. Inflorescence 1, infrafoliar, inserted 2 nodes below the crown, up to 3 times branched; prophyll 62 cm, 10 cm wide, inserted 5 cm above base, 1. peduncular bract 57 cm, 5 cm wide at base, 10 cm wide apically, inserted 12 cm above prophyll, 2. peduncular bract (reminiscent of) 27 cm, 6 cm wide, inserted 20 cm above 1. peduncular bract; peduncle 63 cm, 7 cm wide at base, 4.5 cm wide near rachis, flattened 2.5 cm thick, covered with whitish tomentum; rachis 48 cm, green covered with white/green tomentum; 1. order archillae 17, upper 9 simple, lower 1. order rachillae 26 cm, pedunculate for 11 cm, 3 cm wide at base, 2. order rachillae 9, 8 upper simple, the lower bifurcate, 30 cm, 1 cm wide, upper 1. order rachillae 27 cm, 1 cm wide. Infructescences 3, infrafoliar, to three times branched; peduncle 64 cm, 8 cm wide at base, 5 cm wide near rachis, recurring, pointing downwards; rachis 54 cm, 1. order rachillae 19, upper 9 simple, these 29 cm, 1 cm wide; fruits (immature) green, 13 mm x 12 mm; fruits (mature) globose, bluish black, 15 mm diam, mesocarp fibrous fleshy, violet.

fieldNotes: Height approx 18m. Two were felled here growing close together. A tall palm, carrying fruit in very good heath. ETHNOBOTANY: GK cut open the tree to gather the palm heart, which was shared with everyone to eat; she also carried some home. The fruits when green are also edible. When they are mature, bats eat them. When they fall to the ground, deer eat them. The wood is hard and. LOCAL NAME: Tumduám (Shiwiar); Bambil (Quichua, but commonly used).

According to Julio Billous. Dupl. QCA, QCNE

fieldNotes: Solitary tree, 7.5 cm tall. Old leafbases persistent to ca. 1 m above the ground. Trunk without spines, leafscars sculpturing the stem in a caracteristic pattern. Distance between leafscars uneven. Up to 5 cm. Leaves ca. 25, diam.: 5.8 x 1.7 m, leafbase light grey with a dense network of woolly fibres. No. of pinnae: 2 x 121, insertion on rachis reduplicate. Pinnae more or less aggregated in groups basally. Pinnae dark green dorsally, lighter green ventrally. Plants dioecious. Both male and female inflorescences collected. Male infloresce pendent to 1.5 m, yellow from protruding anthers. Female inflorescence globose to 40 cm in diam.

fieldNotes: Palma en potrero, muy abundante en esta zona (en potreros y en bosque); tallo ca. 3 m alto; pecíolo 36-47 cm l.; lámina 620-633 cm l.; folíolos 111-115 x lado, hasta 90-99 cm l; pedúnculo inflorescencia masculina 43 cm l.; raquis 210 cm l.; espata 110 cm l. x 24.5 cm a.; pedicelo de cada flor 7.5 cm l. x 1 cm a.; flor masculina 5 cm l., diámetros 4.5 y 6.6 cm; infrutescencia muy pesada, globosa, una es 44.5 x 41 cm, otra es 43 cm x 43 cm; segmento de infrutescencia café, 13 cm l. x 8.5 cm a.; semilla grisácea, subelipsoide, 7 cm l. x 5 cm ancho. Nombre Vulgar: "tagua"; se exportan semillas a Europa para hacer botones.

fieldNotes: Ceaspitose palm. Stem 480 cm, DBH: 7 cm. Leafsheath and petiole 84 cm, leafsheaths form pseudocrownshaft - 90 cm long and 12 cm in diam., rachis 195 cm, 45 pinnae per side which are regularly distributed and inserted in one plane. Infrafoliar buds, inflorescences and infructescences inserted in the five apical nodes. Inflorescence: peduncle 9.5 cm, rachis 33 cm, number of rachillae: 68. Infructescence: peduncle 8 cm, rachis 31 cm, number of rachillae: 62.

fieldNotes: Solitary palm. Stem 450 cm, DBH: 15 cm, with green glabrous crownshaft, 75 cm long, and with 13 stiltroots (diam. 6 cm) armed with small spines. Seven leaves, petiole 155 cm, rachis 152 cm, with 20 pinnae on each side. Three infrafoliar infructescences with green fruits, peduncle 32 cm, rachis 14 cm, with 11 rachillae. Vernancular name: Chingu (Quichua). Stiltroots used to make raspador to grind green bananas (verdes). Useful for this purpose because of the spines. The trunks serve as house pots and for floors in the houses.

fieldNotes: Árbol 35 m de altura, fuste 20 m de largo casi cilíndrico, DAP 45 cm, monopódico, posiblemente ramificación verticilada. No raíces tablares. Corteza 2 cm de grosor, completamente dura, escamosa. Las escamas hasta 3 cm delargo, 1 cm de ancho; corteza interna rojiza (casi color carne), granulada, practicamentei nolora, exudando pequeñas gotas de látex amarillo, espeso, pegajoso, volviéndose marrón al cabo de 15 minutos. Hojas completamente coriáceas y quebradizas. Flores fragantes, verde claro, anteras marrón. Ramitas tridivididas.

fieldNotes: Arbusto de 2 m, estéril, látex naranja. Uso medicinal, raíces colectadas son cocidas, de esta cocción beben -a solas- las mujeres que tienen exagerao flujo menstrual (hemorragias), una vez por noche por dos noches para que se normalice su flujo. Nombre chapalaachi: pujpujquemu tape. Informante: Ch. 2 (Sr. José Quinto Añapa, varón, 32 años, nativo de Calle Mansa). Proyecto "Etnobotánica comparativa entre los Chachis y los Afroesmeraldeños de la zona de amortiguamiento occidental de la Reserva Cotacachi-Cayapas". Convenio ECOCIENCIA-SUBIR.

Nombre chapalaachi: pujpujquemu tape. Informante: Ch. 2 (Sr. José Quinto Añapa, varón, 32 años, nativo de Calle Mansa). Proyecto "Etnobotánica comparativa entre los Chachis y los Afroesmeraldeños de la zona de amortiguamiento occidental de la Reserva Cotacachi-Cayapas". Convenio ECOCIENCIA-SUBIR.

fieldNotes: Hierba de 0.6 m de alto, estéril, hojas de haz verde y envés violeta. MEDICINAL, cuando una persona ha sido afectada -no en forma fatal -por el contacto con una culebra "podridora" (Boa constrictor), se mezclan cuatro hojas de esta planta en media o en una taza de agua y se da de beber al afectado por tres veces diarias hasta que mejore. Nombre chapalaachi: "pe piin tape". Nombre en español: "hierba para podridora".
FieldNotes: Hierba de 0.6 m de alto, estéril, hojas de haz verde y envés violeta. MEDICINAL, cuando una persona ha sido afectada -no en forma fatal -por el contacto con una culebra "podridora" (Boa constrictor), se mezclan cuatro hojas de esta planta en media o en una taza de agua y se da de beber al afectado por tres veces diarias hasta que mejore. fieldNotes: Arbusto de 2 m de alto, estéril, sin látex ni glándulas. Nombre chapalaachi: ?jupihuallu?. Nombre en español: ?vara negro?. Categoria(s) de uso (s): Medicinal, las ramas se secan al fuego, luego son molidaas y cernidas para obtener un polvo fino que se pone en las llagas o cortes una vez por día hasta que cicatricen. Las hojas tambien suelen ser masticadas y el bolo obtenido es puesto sobre los cortes frescos para acelerar su cicatrización. Informante: ?Ch 2? (Sr. josé Quinto Añapa, varón, 32 años, nativo de Calle Mansa).

fieldNotes: Unbranched or 2-branched tree, 8m tall, 9 cm dbh. Flowers and fruits cauline, sessile to subsessile. Calyx green; corolla pinkish-white in bud, pearl-white, the petals erect and adaxially concave until post anthesis, cleistogamous?; stamens 2/3 basally fused. Fruits prominently ribbed when fresh, green and brown variegated, 1 seeded. Leaf blades to ca 150 x 40 cm, with sunken dots beneath, ca 46 pairs of lateral nerves. Litter trapper species. Infrequent. Sample for DNA.

fieldNotes: Árbol de 15-16 m; 28.6 cm DAP. Fuste recto. Raices tablares. Corteza externa fisurada, café-clara; interna color manteca; grosor 1 cm; se oxida rapidamente a negro. Hojas verdes brillosas el haz, opacas el envés. Inflorescencias en panículas rojas. Flores blancas con 5 pétalos blancos; época de floración Julio. Copa frondosa con ramificación dicotómica. Usos: construcción de casas. Nombre vulgar: colca
